title: extApps.xml file is unencrypted!!!
author: yossiuzan
body_snippet:
<!--
extApps.xml file is plain text and passwords can be extracted from there.
can the file be encrypted?
-->

<!-- Bug -->
|Detail|Value|
|--:|---|
|Operating system | Windows 10 x64 |
|mRemoteNG version| 1.75.7008  |


<!-- Feature Request -->
<!-- If you file a feature request, please delete the bug section -->

iterations.description: extApps.xml is intended to hold external app templates and use runtime replacement tokens (for example, `%PASSWORD%`) instead of storing sensitive values directly, so file-level encryption is not required.

comments.author: sparerd
comments.snippet:
To my knowledge, it has never been encrypted. Typically, when sensitive data (such as a password) is required, it is provided via a replacement parameter to the external app. So in the arguments text you might have `/p:%PASSWORD%`. Then, you can run that external app from a connection you define in your connection tree. This takes the password set in the connection (which is saved securely) and provides it to the external app.

If you have a use case where this does not work, or for some reaso...

notes:
AI triage (codex): extApps.xml is intended to hold external app templates and use runtime replacement tokens (for example, `%PASSWORD%`) instead of storing sensitive values directly, so file-level encryption is not required.
Approach: Close as by-design and document that credentials should be passed via replacement parameters rather than hardcoded in extApps definitions.
